newsitem.title: USA: N. Ireland politicians regret Robinson departure.
newsitem.headline: N. Ireland politicians regret Robinson departure.

text.p: Two of Northern Ireland's political leaders who are involved in the peace process said on Wednesday they regretted Irish President Mary Robinson's decision not to seek re-election.

"She will be a tough act to follow," Belfast Social Democratic and Labor Party (SDLP) councillor Alex Attwood said in an interview with Reuters before speaking at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government.

"She came in originally standing for equality for women and latterly it became standing for equality for everyone, the poor, community," added Attwood, whose party represents the moderate nationalist view in the Northern Ireland conflict.

Billy Hutchinson of the pro-British Progressive Unionist Party, who was also at the university to speak about Northern Ireland, said Robinson "had an understanding ... that was more acceptable to the Unionists. But like Alex, I believe Ireland has changed so fundamentally, that it is more confident in its role in Europe and in its identity that somebody (like Robinson) will come forward."

Robinson, who announced earlier on Wednesday she would not seek re-election, had been suggested as a possible United Nations secretary-general and there was speculation in Ireland that she could be offered a top U.N. human rights post.
